description: Systematic harvest of history domain (47 experiments, 0 lessons) to reduce F-IS7 edge-loss rate
method: Two parallel expert agents scanned F-HIS1 (34 experiments) and F-HIS2 (13 experiments). Identified 6 novel patterns across the two frontiers. Distilled into 2 lessons.
patterns_found: Grounding floor theorem: automatic fields produce 1/3 compliance floor
Session-boundary tagging decay: voluntary compliance evaporates within 1-2 sessions
Lane churn masquerades as grounding improvement (active-row-count confound)
Inversions vs missing-links are distinct failure modes
Lane-only artifacts are upstream indicator of zero-conversion burial
cross_domain_connections: empathy (F-EMP3): accuracy degrades with concurrency — same shape as grounding decay
dark matter (L-574, L-583): unthemed lessons and ungrounded lanes are both 'encoded but unretrievable'
game-theory (F-GAM3): strict contract tags don't persist across sessions — same Nash equilibrium

edge_loss_impact.note: History domain was 100% loss; now 95.7%. Global rate needs re-measurement at S360.

verdict: CONFIRMED: history harvest gap closed partially. 2 lessons from 47 experiments (4.3% conversion). The 0% floor was caused by the irony that the historian domain itself had the worst provenance tracking.
